METS:xmlData.entity:description: Prispevek temelji na političnih pomenih fantomskih meja, ki se nenehno brišejo in premikajo ter na predstavah o migraciji v spreminjajoči se geografiji in nenehnem fenomenološkem razvoju, podvrženem "kulturni mumifikaciji" (Bhabha), družbeni poroznosti, nenehni agoniji in izbrisu predhodne kulture v balkanskem migracijskem sindromu. Po razpadu nekdanje jugoslovanske konfederacije in nasilnem oblikovanju meja smo priča obuditvi "izmuzljivih" kulturnih mejnosti, ki jih predstavljajo umetniki kot izseljeni obmejni prebivalci. Izbruh vojn v nekdanji Jugoslaviji je povzročil nastanek novih meja, "iznajdevanje tradicije" (Hobsbawm), brezciljno razseljevanje, premike in potovanja ter nostalgijo po izgubljenem prostoru, ki jo je spodbudilo politično razbitje Jugoslavije. Popotnik, ki išče dom, mi še vedno pomeni izziv pri raziskovanju. V prestavitvi se bom osredotočila na srbsko umetnico Tanjo Ostojić, ki se je med vojno izselila v Berlin in ki razgrajuje, naseljuje, premešča, iznajdeva ter postavlja pod vprašaj nevidne mejnosti. Obravnavam njena umetniška dela o mejah iz niza Crossing Borders (tj. Looking for a Husband with an EU passport, Waiting for a Visa, Illegal Border Crossing – najnovejše delo je v bistvu projekt, ki bolje predstavlja dediščino upravnih meja in pojem fantomske meje). Meje so opredeljene kot liminalni prostori, jaz pa se ukvarjam z naslednjim vprašanjem: je res tako pomembno zarisovati ločnice, karte in zemljevide, ko pa je svet postal kulturno liminalen, pretočen, "kreoliziran" (Hannerz)? Predstavila bom ugotovitve iz pogovorov z italijansko-slovenskim novinarjem dr. Stefanom Luso in hrvaško pisateljico iz Istre Slavenko Drakulić, pri čemer se bom oprla na premeščanje oblik pripadnosti in samoopredelitve, ki razkrivajo medsebojna razmerja procesov kulturne mutacije od skupnega prostorskega spomina do kolektivne kulturne amnezije, iznajdevanja preteklosti in poustvarjanja prihodnosti v prehodnih privatizacijskih procesih, ki povzročajo izgubo kulturnega spomina nekdanje Jugoslavije. Moj cilj je ponovno razmisliti o medsebojno povezanih pomenih kartiranja v mejnih prostorih, ki so postali marginalizirani, izločeni, diasporni, hkrati pa središče in jedro ustvarjalnosti, kognitivne anksioznosti, gibanj, ki ustvarjajo različne identitete, ter nepredvidljivih smeri.

The paper draws on political meanings of phantom-borders which are perpetually blurred and shifted and notions of migration in tidal geography in continuous phenomenological evolution, undergoing “cultural mummification” (Bhabha), societal porosity, continued agony and erasure of preexisting culture in the Balkan’s migration syndrome. After the dissolution of the former Yugoslavian Confederation and the violent borders generation, we are witnessing a revival of “quick sand” cultural boundaries performed by artists as exiling border inhabitants. The outbreak of the wars in Former Yugoslavia has produced new map of borders, “reinvention of the tradition” (Hobsbawm), flows of non-targeted displacements and dislocations, indeterminate journeys, and nostalgia for a lost space instigated by the political shattering of Yugoslavia. The wanderer in search for home remains challenging for my research. During my presentation I shall focus on the Serbian artist, expatriated in Berlin during the war, Tanja Ostojic, who is disintegrating, inhabiting, misplacing, reinventing and questioning invisible boundaries. I argue her border-artworks Crossing Borders Series (i.e. Looking for a Husband with an EU passport, Waiting for a Visa, Illegal Border Crossing – the latest is in a nutshell the project which better represent the administrative border legacy and the notion of phantom border). The borders are argued as liminal spaces; the question I am tackling is the following: is it so important to draw boundaries, charts and maps when the world has turned culturally liminal, flow, “creolizing” (Hannerz)? I will thus present findings from interviews with the Italo-Slovenian journalist from Koper, Dr. Stefano Lusa and with the Croatian writer, from Istria, Ms. Slavenka Drakulic drawing on misplacing forms of belonging and self-definition that unveil interrelations of cultural mutation processes from common spatial memory towards collective cultural amnesia, reinvention of the past and recreation of the future in the transitory privatization processes provoking forms of detriment of the cultural memory of former Yugoslavia. The goal is to rethink the interconnected mapping meanings in the bordering spaces, which have become marginalized, detached, diasporic but at the same time a center and a nucleus of creativity, cognitive anxiety, differential identities proliferating movements and unpredictable trajectories.
